comments:
WorkspaceBundleModel.updateTimeStamp has this code:

updateTimeStamp(fUnderlyingResource.getLocation().toFile());

This results in a NPE when getLocation() returns null.

This hampers EFS's support for pluggable file systems, a feature our project relies on. Are there any plans to address this?

John, I was under the impression that PDE will not be affected by the new EFS support.

We can put all the null checks in the world everywhere we use IProject.getLocation(), but I need to understand why and when that call returns null.

Wassim, John can confirm this when he has a chance, but the the API for getLocation() changed to include this:

"(...) This method also returns null if called on a resource that is not stored in the local file system. For such resources getLocationURI() should be used instead."

The other cases it returns null are the same as before (see IResource#getLocation()).
Re: my own comment 2, that NPE has nothing to do with bug 92021, I got confused by the method names.

I have been discussing this with Rafael.

I didn't think it would be important for PDE to fully adopt EFS as we have tried to do in the rest of the SDK.  The restriction is that development of plugins against alternative file systems won't be supported.  It turns out I was wrong, because Rafael is interested in doing this.  In Rafael's case he is creating a wrapper around the local file system, so I might be able to use some wizardry to make it work for him (see bug 129238).

Having said that, it has always been possible since 1.0 for IResource.getLocation() to return null.  The most common case is where the resource belongs to a non-existent project.  PDE should minimally be guarding against null and failing more gracefully.  From browsing all callers of IResource.getLocation() in PDE, there are several places that do this already.
Longer term, it may be worthwhile to get off java.io.File in the future to support development of plugins stored in other file systems.  Many of the references to java.io.File in PDE would be trivial to fix (and would actually yield performance benefits).  Some cases involve interaction with OSGi, which knows nothing about EFS, so these cases are trickier.  They would likely require changing API to use pure InputStream/OutputStream rather than explicitly relying on java.io.File. This would be a non-trivial amount of work.
Reducing severity to normal as per John's comment.

Further details: I'm not using special EFS's for any projects, or using linked resources.  I recently deleted one project that is a prerequisite of others.  My workspace was also in a weird state: some projects got closed somehow, and when I reopened them they only had the .project file showing.  Refreshing the project brought back the contents.  I refreshed the whole workspace, but still get this error shortly after startup.
Rafael points out that I did, in fact, have some projects with a different EFS (unbeknownst to me).
